Award.AwardTitle: Scope and Applications of Amide Ligation of Hydroxyamines
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this New award, the Chemical Synthesis Program supports Professor Michael C. Pirrung of the University of California-Riverside in a project investigating reactions that add an amino acid to a peptide chain, thus extending the chain. Three different amino acids will be employed in these reactions, which build peptide chains. This project focuses on broadening the methods available for building peptides and proteins. Such reactions are of far reaching importance in diverse areas of organic and biological chemistry. Hence, these methods will expand the synthetic toolboxes of a wide range of researchers in the biomedical sciences. This project will also provide training in organic synthesis and peptide chemistry to students, from undergraduates to post-doctorals, including those from groups historically underrepresented in the sciences.

The project will study peptide bond forming reactions between serine and mildly activated C-terminal peptide esters. These reactions, which will be extended to threonine and homoserine, will expand the scope of peptide forming reactions and help to alleviate problems of concentration and scalability. The viability of the method will be tested through the synthesis of naturally occurring peptide sequences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

 

This project developed new methods for the preparation of large peptides, a class of biological molecules with chemical structures like beads on a chain, that are very attractive as pharmaceuticals. This work is related to a large body of current research involving piecing together protein structures from smaller segments, but it goes significantly beyond it by applying the reactions at high concentrations in organic solvents. It therefore expands the limits of peptide synthesis from past practices. Several desirable peptides were prepared using this technique, including one that neutralizes lethal toxins from snake venoms. Another desirable feature of the work is that it is quite environmentally friendly. The absolute amounts of peptides produced from a given reaction are much larger and therefore the amounts of waste products are far smaller than past practices.

 

Because peptides are being increasingly used as drugs, methods to prepare them in large quantities are important for advances in medical sciences. Surprisingly, production of larger peptides and proteins by biotechnology does not dominate the market; molecules even as large as 30-40 units are being manufactured using chemical synthesis methods. Therefore, methods like ours that enhance the chemical preparation of peptide therapeutics will make essential drugs more accessible and reduce their costs.

 

Broader impact

 

Many students were trained in the practice of peptide synthesis in this work. This is one of the core fields of the chemical sciences, and maintaining expertise in this area is crucial to fulfill employment needs in the chemical and pharmaceutical industries. A total of six chemistry students worked on this project, including two women and one underrepresented minority. Broadening the participation of underrepresented groups in STEM research at the academic level enhances their employment opportunities after training, and broadens the diversity in the STEM workforce.
